Situation1: The passenger’s train leaves soon and the station is across town
Situation2: They witness a serious wrongdoing, such as corruption or harm to others, and feel compelled to take decisive moral action.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my dashboard; the passenger in my backseat was anxiously tapping his foot, glancing at his watch every few seconds. “Please, bhaiya, my train leaves in twenty minutes. Can you get me to the station fast?” he pleaded. As a taxi driver, I knew my job was to get him there safely and on time, and I felt the pressure mounting. I took a shortcut through a narrow lane, hoping to save precious minutes. Suddenly, I saw a group of men roughing up a street vendor, snatching his money and pushing him to the ground. My heart pounded. As a Hindu, I was taught to stand up for dharma, to act when I saw injustice. But the passenger’s voice broke through my thoughts, “Please, hurry!” I gripped the steering wheel, torn between my duty to my passenger and my responsibility to intervene. The seconds ticked by, and I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me, demanding action in opposite directions.
